Article_title: A Detection Probability Model for Aerial Surveys of Mule Deer
Authors: Zabransky C. J.,…& C. A. Deyoung
Institution: Caesar Kleberg Wildlife Research Institute, Texas A&M University-Kingsville, Kingsville, TX 78363, USA
Study_objective: Develop and test a detection probability model for aerial surveys of mule deer in this region.
Locality: Trans-Pecos region (4 sites: TP1, TP2, TP3, TP4)
Method_record_interaction: They used data from tagged deer and logistic regression; frequency tables to estimate collinearity between variables.

Article_title: A note on the behavior of feral cattle in the Chihuahuan Desert of Mexico
Institution: Instituto de Ecologia, A.C. Centro Regional Durango / Departamento de Botanica, Escuela Nacional de Ciencias Biologicas-IPN
Study_objective: Compare patterns of habitat use and behavior between domestic and feral livestock.
Locality: Mapimi Biosphere Reserve
Main_methods: Capture and installation of telemetry equipment
Method_record_interaction: Telemetry, Kernel method for home range; G test for habitat preference

Article_title: Animal disturbances promote shrub maintenance in a desertified grassland
Authors: Eldridge, D. J.,...& Duval, B. D.
Institution: Department of Environment & Climate Change, Ecology & Evolution Research Centre, School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences, University of New South Wales / Department of Biological Sciences, Northern Arizona University,
Study_objective: Know what is the effect on the vegetation of the structures created by Taxidea taxus and Dipodomys spp.
Locality: 40 km north of Las Cruces, New Mexico
Protected area (another): El USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range & the New Mexico State University Chihuahuan Desert Rangeland Research Centre
Method_record_interaction: Measurement of vegetation density around structures created by Taxidea, Dipodomys, ants, Neotoma, etc...soil analysis.

Article_title: Apprehension affecting foraging patterns and landscape use of mule deer in arid environments
Institution: Centro Regional, Instituto de Ecología, AC / Centro Universitario de la Costa Sur, Universidad de Guadalajara
Study_objective: Understand how predation risk affects mule deer habitat selection.
Locality: Laboratorio del Desierto, Mapimi Biosphere Reserve (MBR)
Main_methods: Deer feed plots were located at different sites with different risk levels.
Method_record_interaction: Evaluation of consumption at the different sites
Comments: They are trying to find out how the threat of these predators determines the selection and foraging patterns of mule deer.

Article_title: Does shrub invasion indirectly limit grass establishment via seedling herbivory? A test at grassland-shrubland ecotones
Authors: Bestelmeyer, B. T.,...& Peters, D. P. C.
Institution: USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range and Jornada Basin LTER, Las Cruces
Study_objective: 1. To test the prediction that the number of seedlings killed by herbivores would increase from the grass-dominated to shrub-dominated positions of ecotones (seedling herbivory hypothesis). 2. To test the seedling herbivory hypothesis at two Chihuahuan Desert sites that differ in the dominant encroaching shrub species, the overall abundance of grass, and overall abundances of rodents and lagomorphs.
Locality: Jornada Basin Long-Term Ecological Research, Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge
Protected area (another): Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge
Method_record_interaction: Consumption of seeds, abundance of rodents

Article_title: Evaluating potential factors affecting puma Puma concolor abundance in the Mexican Chihuahuan Desert
Authors: John W. Laundré, Daniel Nuñez López
Institution: Instituto de Ecologia, A.C., Centro Regional Durango / Instituto de Ecologia, A.C., Centro Regional Chihuahua
Study_objective: To identify the variables that explain the differences in cougar abundance between two mountains of the Chihuahuan Desert.
Locality: El Cuervo, Sierra Rica
Main_methods: Trace searches, interviews with villagers, counting of fecal clusters
Method_record_interaction: Fecal groups for calculating prey density
Comments: The second study site is within the APFyF. They also measured the density of two domestic prey: Bos taurus, Equus feris and E. africanus.

Article_title: Factors Influencing Foraging Habitats of Mule Deer (Odocoileus hemionus) in the San Andres Mountains, New Mexico
Authors: Brock D. Hoenes And Louis C. Bender
Institution: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife / Extension Animal Sciences and Natural Resources, New Mexico State University, Las Cruces
Study_objective: Document habitat characteristics to relate to deer foraging needs.
Locality: The San Andres Mountains area encompasses ca. 11,000 km2 including San Andres National Wildlife Refuge, White Sands Missile Range, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Test Facility, and United States Department of Agriculture Jornada Experimental Range.
Protected area (another): San Andres National Wildlife Refuge, White Sands Missile Range?
Main_methods: Point-intercept transect to determine composition and coverage

Institution: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife / Extension Animal Sciences and Natural Resources, New Mexico State University, Las Cruces
Study_objective: Document habitat characteristics to relate to deer foraging needs.
Locality: The San Andres Mountains area encompasses ca. 11,000 km2 including San Andres National Wildlife Refuge, White Sands Missile Range, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Test Facility, and United States Department of Agriculture Jornada Experimental Range.
Protected area (another): San Andres National Wildlife Refuge, White Sands Missile Range?
Main_methods: Point-intercept transect to determine composition and coverage

Article_title: First insights into the fecal bacterial microbiota of the black–tailed prairie dog (Cynomys ludovicianus) in Janos, Mexico
Institution: Facultad de Ciencias Biológicas, Universidad Juárez del Estado de Durango, Gómez Palacio, Durango, México,
Study_objective: Describe the abundance and diversity of fecal microorganisms.
Locality: Janos Biosphere Reserve
Protected area (another): Reserva de la Biosfera de Janos
Main_methods: Fecal sample collection and DNA analysis
Method_record_interaction: Fecal sample collection and DNA analysis
Comments: 333 species were identified but only 3 had a known name

Article_title: Foraging in the Landscape of Fear, the Predator’s Dilemma: Where Should I Hunt?
Institution: Instituto de Ecología, A.C., Centro Regional Durango
Study_objective: Test the hypotheses: we predicted that coyotes should be more abundant in areas of lower jackrabbit abundance; coyotes will hunt where jackrabbits are less abundant but more vulnerable. Secondly, we tested the prediction that there should be equal or higher occurrence of jackrabbits in coyote diets in the low versus the high jackrabbit areas;
Locality: Mapimi Biosphere Reserve
Main_methods: Collection of feces and estimation of prey abundance
Method_record_interaction: Collection of feces and estimation of prey abundance

Article_title: Foraging of the bobcat (Lynx rufus) in the Chihuahuan Desert: generalist or specialist?
Authors: Juan Carlos López-Vidal, Juan Carlos López-Vidal,
Institution: Departamento de Zoología, Escuela Nacional de Ciencias Biológicas, Instituto Politécnico Nacional / Departamento de Zoología, Instituto de Biología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México
Study_objective: To determine if the diet of bobcats can be explained by foraging theory, e.g., bobcats are selecting for the most profitable prey.

Main_methods: Collection of feces and estimation of prey abundance

Article_title: Graminivory by Dipodomys ordii and Dipodomys merriami on four species of perennial grasses
Authors: Michael P. Sipos, William R. Gould
Institution: Department of Fisheries and Wildlife Sciences, New Mexico State University / University Statistics Center New Mexico State University
Study_objective: To test the hypotheses: that these 2 partially sympatric species differ in their selectivity for grasses in ways that reflect differences between the habitats in which they typically occur. In addition, we hypothesized that the water content of the grasses was sufficient to explain any demonstrated selectivity.
Locality: ca. 56 km NE of Las Cruces, New Mexico, on the United States Department of Agriculture's Jornada Experimental Range and New Mexico State University's Chihuahuan Desert Rangelands Research Center.

Article_title: Habitat and forage selection by the american beaver (Castor canadensis) on a regulated river in the chihuahuan desert
Authors: Isidro A. Barela, Jennifer K. Frey
Institution: Department of Fish, Wildlife, and Conservation Ecology, New Mexico State University
Study_objective: To examine habitat selection and foraging habits of beavers along the Rio Grande in southern New Mexico. In addition, we made observations about the use of den sites, food caches, and other aspects of their natural history.

Method_record_interaction: Collection of plants cut down by beavers

Article_title: Prevalence and Genetic Diversity of Bartonella Strains in Rodents from Northwestern Mexico

Article_title: Rapid Decline of a Grassland System and Its Ecologicaland Conservation Implications
Institution: Instituto de Ecología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México D.F., México / Instituto de Ecología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México D.F., México
Study_objective: To evaluate the effect of grassland ecosystem transformation on the black-tailed prairie dog community and how the decline in black-tailed prairie dog populations influences the plant and animal communities that establish there.
Locality: Región de Janos-Casas Grandes
Protected area (another): Reserva de la Biosfera de Janos
Main_methods: In the results it is said that the plants had signs of prairie dog clipping.
Comments: The study is observational/experimental, but the recording of the interaction is because they observed signs in the ephedra plants that they had been consumed by this mammal.

Article_title: Rapid response of a grassland ecosystem to an experimental manipulation of a keystone rodent and domestic livestock
Institution: Instituto de Ecología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México y Department of Biology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque / Instituto de Ecología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México
Study_objective: Evaluate the relationships between cattle and prairie dogs and the effects of the presence/absence of these species on other organisms and grassland ecosystems.
Locality: Región de Janos-Casas Grandes
Protected area (another): Reserva Ecológica El Uno de Nature Conservancy
Main_methods: They conducted a 2-year experiment based on a 2x2 factorial design with 4 blocks distributed as follows: presence of prairie dogs and cattle (þPþC), cattle only (PþC), prairie dogs only (þPC) and where none of the species were present (PC). In each of these we measured percent canopy cover, canopy height, grasshopper sampling each autumn throughout surveys, and other mammal activity.
Method_record_interaction: To see the effect of each experiment, the activity of banner-tailed kangaroo rat and gophers was recorded through the percentage of ground disturbance cover as an indication of their presence in the area. As well as cottontail rabbit fecal counts.

Article_title: Reduced rodent biodiversity destabilizes plant populations
Institution: Department of Biology, Saint Louis University, Missouri-USA / Department of Biology, Saint Louis University, Missouri-USA
Study_objective: Assess the effect of granivorous rodent reduction over plant dynamics.
Locality: Portal
Main_methods: Monitoring and quantification of plant abundance in plots with different rodent exclusion/inclusion treatments.
Method_record_interaction: Plant dynamics in the presence of rodent exclusion

Article_title: Reintroducing a keystone burrowing rodent to restore an arid North American grassland: challenges and successes
Institution: Department of Wildlife, Humboldt State University, Arcata / Natural Resources & Environmental Science, University of Nevada, Reno
Study_objective: Evaluate the population status and dynamics of three newly established (since 2010) Gunnison’s prairie dog colonies at the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge in central New Mexico, and the impact of their reintroduction on grassland wildlife.
Locality: Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge (SNWR), located in Socorro County, Los Piños Mountains
Coordinates: NAD 83, UTM Zone 13 N, Northing 3,800,855 Easting 349,376
Method_record_interaction: Occupancy models and comparison between treatments
Comments: Positive interaction, the puppy modifies the habitat to make it favorable for these species.

Article_title: Relación espacial entre nopales y madrigueras de rata magueyera Neotoma leucodon en Mapimí, México
Institution: Agrupación de Voluntariado Ambiental de Santa Fe-AUCA, Granada-España / Departamento de Biología de la Conservación, Estación Biológica de Doñana Sevilla-España.
Study_objective: Describe and quantify the distance relationship between nopales cactus and magueyera rat burrows in Mapimí, Mexico.
Locality: Laboratorio del Desierto
Main_methods: Samplingo of burrows in different nopalera habitats
Comments: The study is carried out with prior knowledge of this interaction.

Article_title: Report of Physaloptera praeputialis (Von Linstow 1889, Nematoda) in Mountain Lion (Puma concolor, Linneaus 1771)
Authors: Martinez Guerrero, J. H. Herrera Casio, H.
Institution: Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria Zootecnia de la Universidad Juarez del Estado de Durango
Journal: Journal of Animal and Veterinary Advances
Study_objective: Register parasite for puma
Locality: Mapimi Biosphere Reserve

Article_title: Resistance of creosotebush to mammalian herbivory: temporal consistency and browsing-induced changes
Institution: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico
Study_objective: To evaluate both constitutive and induced resistance in a single plant-herbivore system, and to test the relative contributions of both types of historical effects to herbivory patterns.
Locality: Condado de Socorro
Protected area (another): El Refugio Nacional para la Vida Silvestre de Sevilleta
Main_methods: Temporal herbivory patterns were recorded by monitoring Creosotebush shrubs in different plots. To evaluate plant resistance, the degree of browsing was used as an indicator, since higher browsing indicates lower resistance.
Method_record_interaction: Herbivory monitoring in plots with the study plant.

Article_title: Response of lizard community structure to desert grassland restoration mediated by a keystone rodent
Institution: Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Sciences, University of Illinois, Urbana / USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range, New Mexico State University,
Study_objective: Evaluate the influence of restoration treatments on lizard community structure.
Locality: Desierto de Chihuahua central cerca de Hatch
Main_methods: Monitoring of the lizard community in the different treatments, as well as the influence of their characteristics on the Aspidoscelis uniparens lizard.
Method_record_interaction: Observation of the rat-kangaroo mounds associated with the treatments
Comments: The interaction consists in the fact that the abundance of the lizard depends on the mounds of the kangaroo rat as it benefits from it.

Article_title: Ringtail (Bassariscus astutus) Ecology And Behavior In Central New Mexico, USA
Institution: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico
Study_objective: Study the ecology, behavior and diet of Ringtails (Bassariscus astutus) in Juniperus monosperma forest.
Locality: Cordillera de Los Pinos del Refugio Nacional de Vida Silvestre de Sevilleta (NWR) y tierras adyacentes de la Oficina de Administración de Tierras del Departamento de Agricultura de EE. UU., en el condado de Socorro

Study_objective: Study the ecology, behavior and diet of ringtails (Bassariscus astutus) in Juniperus monosperma forest.
Locality: Cordillera de Los Pinos del Refugio Nacional de Vida Silvestre de Sevilleta (NWR) y tierras adyacentes de la Oficina de Administración de Tierras del Departamento de Agricultura de EE. UU., en el condado de Socorro
Protected area (another): El Refugio Nacional para la Vida Silvestre de Sevilleta
Main_methods: Field sampling using baited cage traps, telemetry, field examination or necropsy, and fecal collection.

Article_title: Risk factors associated with prevalence of antibodies to Leptospira interrogans in a metapopulation of black-tailed prairie dogs in Mexico
Institution: Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria y Zootécnia, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México / Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria y Zootécnia, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México
Study_objective: Determine whether colony area, density, and proximity to human settlements are associated with the prevalence of Leptospira interrogans antibodies in black-tailed prairie dogs.
Locality: Región de Janos-Casas Grandes
Protected area (another): Reserva de la Biosfera de Janos
Main_methods: Use of traps to capture the species in 11 colonies and blood analysis by microscopic agglutination test for antibody detection.
Method_record_interaction: Analysis of antibodies against the pathogen in blood samples from each prairie dog.

Article_title: ROEDORES EN LA DIETA DE DOS AVES RAPACES NOCTURNAS (BUBO VIRGINIANUS Y TYTO ALBA) EN EL NORESTE DE DURANGO, MÉXICO
Institution: Instituto de Ecología, A.C., Centro Regional Durango, Departamento de Fauna Silvestre, Durango-México
Study_objective: Determine the predator-prey relationship of the Great Horned Owl and the Barn Owl according to the availability of rodents.
Locality: Bolsón de Mapimí
Main_methods: Rodent Samplingo traps and scavenger hunt for pellets

Article_title: Role of reptiles and arthropods in the diet of coyotes in extreme desert areas of northern Mexico
Institution: Instituto de Ecología, Durando, México / Estación Biológica de Doñaña, Sevilla, España
Study_objective: Determining the diet of coyotes (Canis latrans) during the fall.
Locality: Área de Mapimí Bolsón del desierto de Chihuahua
Main_methods: Identification of prey parts through coyote feces collection
Comments: Only the analysis of dams in the Mapimi Biosphere Reserve was taken into account since the other study area is not in the Chihuahuan Desert.

Article_title: Serological Survey of Hantavirus In Rodents From Prairie Dog Ecosystems In Chihuahua, Mexico
Institution: Departamento de Etologıa, Fauna Silvestre y Animales de Laboratorio, Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria y Zootecnia, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México / Departamento de Etologıa, Fauna Silvestre y Animales de Laboratorio, Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria y Zootecnia, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México
Study_objective: Conduct a serological study to detect antibodies against hantavirus in rodents of the Janos-Nuevo Casas Grandes plains dog complex.
Locality: Región de Janos-Casas Grandes

Main_methods: Capture of rodents and blood collection for hantavirus antibody detection.

Article_title: Shrub encroachment creates a dynamic landscape of fear for desert lagomorphs via multiple pathways
Institution: Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Sciences, University of Illinois / Department of Biology, Hobart and William Smith Colleges
Study_objective: Evaluating how shrub encroachment in the Chihuahuan Desert affects the landscape of fear for two sympatric dams.
Locality: Jornada Basin Long Term Ecological Research (LTER)
Main_methods: Measurement of escape distance in a shrub encroachment gradient.
Comments: Indirect interaction, it affects positively as it allows it to escape from predators.

Article_title: Spatial organization of a desert rodent community: food addition and species removal
Institution: Blandy Experimental Farm and Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Virginia, USA / Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of Arizona, USA
Study_objective: To evaluate changes in rodent microhabitat use in response to the presence of Dipodomys sp and food supply.
Locality: desert shrub habitat in south-eastern Arizona
Main_methods: Implementation of treatment plots for the selective exclusion of rodent species. Rodent censuses and characterization of microhabitats.
Method_record_interaction: Census of rodents in the plots

Article_title: The composition of seed banks on kangaroo rat (Dipodomys spectabilis) mounds in a Chihuahuan Desert grassland
Authors: Terri L. Koontz, Heather L. Simpson
Institution: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico
Study_objective: Understand the impact of kangaroo rat burrows on the seed bank.
Locality: Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge Long-term Ecological Research (LTER) site in Socorro
Main_methods: Collecting soil samples in and around burrows
Comments: It does not predate the seeds directly but buries them at such a depth that the seeds cannot germinate, so it can be considered a post-dispersal predation.

Article_title: The Effects of Vertebrate Granivores and Folivores on Plant Community Structure in the Chihuahuan Desert
Institution: Dept of Biology, Univ. of New Mexico
Study_objective: We examine the impacts of granivorous birds and rodents as well as folivorous mammals on winter and summer plant communities by analyzing the effects of selectively excluding these groups from small experimental plots for 11 yr.
Locality: northern Chihuahuan Desert near Portal
Comments: They examined the effects of granivorous and folivorous vertebrates on winter and summer plant communities. It is an experiment where they have patches in which they exclude birds and rodents individually and as a group. The conclusion is that there is an effect of the exclusion of these groups, but they do not specify which vertebrate species influences which plant species.

Study_objective: We examine the impacts of granivorous birds and rodents as well as folivorous mammals on winter and summer plant communities by analyzing the effects of selectively excluding these groups from small experimental plots for 11 yr.
Locality: northern Chihuahuan Desert near Portal
Comments: They examined the effects of granivorous and folivorous vertebrates on winter and summer plant communities. It is an experiment where they have patches in which they exclude birds and rodents individually and as a group. The conclusion is that there is an effect of the exclusion of these groups, but they do not specify which vertebrate species influences which plant species.

Article_title: The landscape of fear habitat use by a predator (Canis latrans) and its main prey (Lepus californicus and Sylvilagus audubonii)
Institution: Instituto de Ecología, A.C., Veracruz-México / Universidad Veracruzana, Facultad de Estadística e Informática LINAE, Veracruz-México
Study_objective: To evaluate the degree of mutual exclusivity of coyote (and their main prey) distributions by testing two models.
Locality: Bolsón de Mapimí
Main_methods: Use of collars for coyote monitoring and assessment of lagomorph density using the pellet-per-area method

Article_title: The measurement of granivory by desert rodents, birds and ants: a comparison of an energetics approach and a seed-dish technique
Institution: Department of Biology and Ecology Center, Utah State University, Logan, Utah
Study_objective: The relative importance of rodents, birds and granivorous ants in four arid ecosystems was examined.
Locality: Oeste de Animas
Main_methods: Energetic approach method and plate experiment with native seeds and commercial millet.
Comments: Mojave Desert data were not taken into account because it is in Utah.
